authorsByline: The Washington Times https://www.washingtontimes.com, Matt Delaney, https://www.washingtontimes.com/staff/matt-delaney/
title: National Guard hits D.C.; federal takeover already nets dozens of arrests, encampment clearings
description: National Guard troops put boots on the ground Tuesday in the District as the White House shared the first batch of federal arrests and warned the city’s homeless they could face jail time amid President Trump’s takeover of the nation’s capital’s policing.
content:
National Guard troops put boots on the ground Tuesday in the District as the White House shared the first batch of federal arrests and warned the city’s homeless they could face jail time amid President Trump’s takeover of the nation’s capital’s policing.

White House spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt said nearly 850 federal agents began patrolling the city Monday evening and took 23 suspects into custody on homicide, gun, drug, drunken-driving and fare evasion charges.

She said the U.S. Park Police cleared 70 homeless camps as well, with the vagrants given the option to seek treatment or a shelter bed.

If they refused, she said they were told they could be arrested or fined for living on sidewalks, underpasses and grassy patches throughout the District.

More than 800 soldiers from the D.C. National Guard also arrived Tuesday morning to assist with the Trump administration’s goal of taming violent crime and general disorder in the capital city.

“These are pre-existing laws that are already on the books, they have not been enforced, which is part of the reason for this nationalizing, or the federalizing of the National Guard to bring in this assistance for law enforcement,” Ms. Leavitt said.

“While we are targeting criminals and trying to remove criminals off of the streets, we also want to make D.C. safe and beautiful,” she said.

The Washington Times contacted the D.C. National Guard about where the troops are being sent.

Attorney General Pam Bondi, the point person for overseeing the emergency declaration, said Tuesday that she met with D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser to lay out how the 30-day period will go.

“We agreed that there is nothing more important than keeping residents and tourists in Washington, D.C. safe from deadly crime,” Ms. Bondi wrote on X.

Just hours after Mr. Trump announced his emergency declaration Monday, the District recorded its 100th homicide for the year.

Metropolitan Police said the deadly shooting erupted on the 1200 block of 12th Street Northwest just before 7 p.m.

Arriving officers found a wounded man, later identified as 33-year-old Tymark Wells, suffering multiple bullet wounds at the scene.

The victim was rushed to a hospital, but police said Mr. Wells died from his injuries around 10:50 p.m.

Police data says killings are down 11% year-over-year in the District.

“Last night, DC suffered the grave milestone of its 100th homicide for 2025,” the D.C. Police Union, which supports the president’s intervention into local public safety matters, said Tuesday in a statement. “Let’s hope this federal intervention leads to real change to the laws in DC that allow this to happen year after year.”

The fatal shooting happened in the same neighborhood where a former federal employee was attacked earlier this month — the incident that inspired Mr. Trump to exert his authority over the District’s public safety infrastructure.

Police said Edward Corisitine was walking to his car with a woman on 14th Street Northwest when a group of teens made comments about stealing the vehicle.

Authorities said Mr. Corisitine pushed his date into the car for her safety and turned to confront the group, who then jumped him.

News of the Aug. 3 attack on the former staffer at the Department of Government Efficiency, already better known because of his online moniker “Big Balls,” got the attention of Mr. Trump, who blasted out social media posts deriding the state of public safety in the District.

About a week later, the president announced his full-scale takeover of the District to crack down on crime.

“Our capital city has been overtaken by violent gangs and bloodthirsty criminals, roving mobs of wild youth, drugged out maniacs, and homeless people, and we’re not going to let it happen anymore,” Mr. Trump said Monday from the White House.

Federal authorities have since been spotted in popular nightlife spots, such as the U Street corridor in Northwest, as well as in the neighborhoods east of the Anacostia River, an area that has long struggled with violent crime and disorder.

Mayor Muriel Bowser, a Democrat, called the president’s move “unsettling and unprecedented,” but said she will follow the law and work with the president during the emergency period.

Metropolitan Police Chief Pamela A. Smith said she has coordinated with U.S. Marshals, who are overseeing the federal deployment, to suggest where agents are most needed.

The D.C. Council, which is almost entirely made up of Democrats, shot back at Mr. Trump’s declaration by saying it was a “manufactured intrusion” and that violent crime is at a 30-year low.

D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb, whose office is largely responsible for prosecuting juvenile crimes in the city, called the White House’s takeover “unlawful” and unnecessary because of a sizable drop in violent crime.

“We are considering all of our options and will do what is necessary to protect the rights and safety of District residents,” Mr. Schwalb posted on X.

According to police statistics, crime has fallen precipitously in the two years since the District saw a generational spike in killings, muggings and carjackings in 2023.

But Mr. Trump disputed those numbers Monday when making his announcement, calling them cooked and unreliable.

He specifically mentioned a high-ranking member of Metropolitan Police who was already under investigation on suspicion of fiddling with crime data to disguise the city’s level of violent incidents.

The White House said the District has the fourth-highest homicide rate in the nation — “ahead” of such other big cities as New York City, Chicago and Atlanta.

The Trump administration also said the rate of nonviolent vehicle theft in the District is more than three times the national average, and carjackings went up 547% between 2018 and 2023.

Outside of violent crime, Mr. Trump aims to rein in the mobs of youth who run amok in Navy Yard and the ATV drivers who swarm city streets.
summary: National Guard troops have been deployed to Washington, D.C., as part of President Trump's takeover of the nation's capital's policing. The White House has shared the first batch of federal arrests and warned the city's homeless that they could face jail time if they live without treatment or a shelter bed. Nearly 850 federal agents began patrolling the city Monday evening and have taken 23 suspects into custody on homicide, gun, drug, drunken-driving and fare evasion charges. The U.S. Park Police also cleared 70 homeless camps and warned that homeless people could be arrested or fined for living on sidewalks, underpasses, and grassy patches throughout the District. More than 800 soldiers from the Washington National Guard have also arrived to assist in the administration's goal of reducing violent crime and disorder in the capital city. The move comes after the District recorded its 100th homicide for the year, with police data indicating killings are down 11% year-over-year in the city.
shortSummary: President Trump's federal takeover of Washington DC has led to numerous arrests and encampments, aiming to reduce violent crime and improve public safety amid ongoing anti-crime measures.
argos_summary: National Guard troops were deployed in Washington, D.C. as part of President Trump's emergency declaration to address rising crime, with nearly 850 federal agents arresting 23 suspects on various charges. The White House also cleared homeless camps, warning individuals they could face arrest if they refused shelter or treatment. While crime statistics indicate a decrease in violent crime, Trump criticized local data as misleading, asserting that the District has a high homicide rate and calling for federal intervention to improve public safety.
